timeline.summary: An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York requested the uploading of documents from the Wisa.doj.gov\cloud\NYS\StAndrews\Shared USvEpstein-2018R01618 InvestigationV*2018 SDNY investigation\Subpoena Returns\Boies Schiller\2019-03-04 Boies Schiller first subpoena response folder into Relativity for the US v. Epstein case. The desired folder structure was “Subpoena Returns” with subfolders “BSF returns” and “BSF first production” to receive the documents.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York requested the upload of documents related to the USAO tt 2018R01618 case (US v. Epstein) into Relativity. The documents were located in a specific folder structure within Usa.doj.gov: clouANYS StAndrews \Shared \ USvEpstein-2018R01618 InvestigationVI 2018 SDNY investigation \Subpoena Returns \ Boies Schiller 2019-03-04 Boies Schiller first subpoena response. The requested structure involved a "Subpoena Returns" folder with subfolders "BSF returns" and "BSF first production" for depositing the documents. The Assistant U.S. Attorney requested confirmation of the upload completion.

The email chain discusses the preparation of documents for Relativity. Specifically, the documents located at several paths within the USAO network (\\Usa.doj.gov\clouANYS\StAndrews\Shared\UUUV4C1-3, \\Usa.doj.gov\cloud\NYS\StAndrews\Shared\UUUV4Q-3, and \\Usa.doj.gov\cloud\NYS\StAndrews\Shared\USvEpstein-2018R01618) containing DVD data should not be loaded into Relativity. The sender requests that the documents within the US v. Epstein folder be organized into a specific folder structure ("Subpoena Returns," "BSF returns," and "BSF first production") for upload to Relativity.  A conversion to a different format is being investigated.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent an email to request the upload of documents related to the USA v. Epstein case into Relativity. The documents were located in a specific folder structure within Usa.doj.gov and were subsequently confirmed to have been loaded into Relativity by the sender.

This document details the process of uploading documents related to the US v. Epstein case to the Relativity platform. The Assistant U.S. Attorney requests that specific folders be created within Relativity, mirroring the existing folder structure for the “BSF returns” documents.  Key instructions include: *   Loading documents from a specific DOJ folder (Usa.doj.gov\clouANYS StAndrews \Shared \ USvEpstein-2018R01618 InvestigationV4 2018 SDNY investigation \Subpoena Returns \ Boies Schiller\ 2019-04-18 Boies Schiller second subpoena response) into a new subfolder called “BSF second production” under “BSF returns.” *   Excluding specific folders and PDF documents from the upload (the “!Original Zips” folder and the three PDF documents). *   Clarifying that DVD-based data (containing video files) should not be uploaded. *   Confirming the desired folder structure for the upload process. Several emails demonstrate coordination and clarification regarding the upload process, ensuring the documents are properly organized and processed within the Relativity system.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney requests the upload of documents related to the US v. Epstein case (USAO11 2018R01618) into Relativity. The documents are located in a specific folder structure within the USA.doj.gov cloud, originating from Boies Schiller.  A separate party notes the documents contain DVD data and requests conversion to a different format, alongside confirmation on how to view video files without a DVD player. Specific file paths containing interview transcripts are listed as items that should *not* be loaded into Relativity due to their DVD-based structure. The request specifies a desired folder structure within Relativity for the uploaded files.

The document outlines the process of uploading documents related to the US v. Epstein case to the Relativity platform. Initially, a request is made to load documents from a specific folder structure (`Usa.doj.gov\ cloud\ NYS \ StAndrews \Shared \ USvEpstein-2018R01618`) into Relativity, maintaining the existing folder structure ("BSF returns" within "Subpoena Returns").  There’s a discussion about the format of the documents (specifically DVD files and needing conversion), and a clarification that DVD-based data should not be loaded into Relativity.  Finally, a list of specific file paths related to DVD-based interviews should be excluded from the upload.

The email chain discusses the transfer of documents related to the US v. Epstein case to Relativity. Specifically, the Assistant U.S. Attorney requests the following actions: 1.  Documents from a folder hosted on Usa.doj.gov should be uploaded to Relativity under the “BSF second production” subfolder within the “BSF returns” subfolder, which should be created within the “Subpoena Returns” subfolder. 2.  Certain files within the source folder (specifically, DVD-related video files and several PDF files) should *not* be uploaded to Relativity. 3.  Confirmation is requested regarding the ability to view the video files independently of a DVD player. 4.  A separate request is made to load a different folder of documents into Relativity for the same case.

The document details the transfer of several sets of documents related to the US v. Epstein case to Relativity for legal analysis. Initially, the documents were in a folder structure with DVD information that needs conversion. Subsequent communications clarify the desired Relativity folder structure: documents should be placed within a subfolder named "BSF second production" under "BSF returns" within the "Subpoena Returns" subfolder. Specific files containing DVD data are to be excluded from the upload. The sender requests updates on the upload progress and confirms the desired folder structure.

Attorney, Boies Schiller lawyers) are coordinating the upload of documents related to the US v. Epstein case to the Relativity platform. Initially, all documents were uploaded, but subsequent emails detail specific instructions for adding additional files related to a “second production” and “BSF returns.” The key requests involve loading documents from a specific DOJ-provided folder structure into Relativity, including avoiding certain files (DVD information, original zip folders) and converting file formats if necessary. One email highlights the presence of DVD-related files within the documents and requests clarification on how to view them independently of a DVD player.
An email exchange concerning the case of *United States v. Epstein* was sent from "Ia" to a redacted contractor. The email is flagged as a "Read: US v. Epstein."
This document is a read (likely a memorandum or email) regarding the case of *US v. Epstein*, sent from “I” to “[REDACTED]” (a USANYS contractor). The email was sent on June 10, 2019.
An email was sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] regarding the case “US v. Epstein,” dated July 2, 2019. The email is marked as a read and of normal importance, with the file identifier EFTA00015569.

On July 19, 2019, Martin Weinberg contacted [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] regarding the US v. Epstein case. Weinberg proposed a call for Tuesday to discuss case management issues, a protective order, and discovery rollout. [REDACTED] responded with a similar proposal for a call on Tuesday.

On July 19, 2019, Martin Weinberg proposed a call to discuss case management issues, a protective order, and discovery rollout related to the US v. Epstein case.  He suggested Tuesday, and the recipient responded that afternoon was preferable. The email thread originated from [REDACTED] to ealS>.
An email was sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] regarding the case of *US v. Epstein*. The email is labeled EFTA00021660 and dated July 24, 2019.

On July 25, 2019, individuals within the Epstein defense team (Martin G. Weinberg, Reid Weingarten, Michael Miller) were coordinating efforts to produce materials related to the US v. Epstein case. Andy was involved in the goal of producing the materials before a conference. Martin Weinberg intended to sign a Protective Order and requested information regarding the discovery's format and expected delivery.

Martin G. Weinberg requested that his team expedite the provision of search warrants, affidavits, and returns related to the US v. Epstein case. Ori inal Messa e responded, stating that an initial electronic discovery production (in native formats like PDFs and JPEGs) would be made no later than Tuesday. Weinberg anticipated a responsive letter by Monday morning, seeking information about the timing and format of the discovery production given the Protective Order and Steptoe IT’s preparation needs.

An email chain discusses edits to a status hearing notification for the US v. Epstein case. One sender indicates they edited previous letters but was unable to make further changes due to a template restriction. Instructions are given to remove the phrase "defendant(s)" from the case caption and to replace specific wording regarding court date changes with alternative language including a contact number for last-minute updates. A separate notification (EFTA00029516) is also referenced.

Martin Weinberg, Esq., contacted Reid Weingarten and Marty to discuss preservation requests related to the US v. Epstein case. He requested clarification on whether he needed to proactively request preservation from the US Attorney’s Office (AUSA) in SD Fla or if the request would be forwarded by Weingarten’s team. Weinberg anticipated a delay in responding due to travel and suggested sending a follow-up letter focusing on notifying other DOJ districts. Weingarten responded, acknowledging the delay and offering to incorporate the letter into their response.

Attorney’s Office — SDNY is discussing edits to status notifications for the case *US v. Epstein*. *   The Assistant uses a template system (VNS) for creating these notifications, with limited editable sections. *   The Assistant is requesting edits to remove “defendant(s)” from the case caption and revise language regarding hearing date changes. *   FBI has exported 4 additional victim names. *   The Assistant is encountering difficulties with the VNS system’s inflexible template and attempting to accommodate requests for specific edits.

On August 7, 2019, Martin G. Weinberg contacted Michael Miller regarding a response to letters sent on July 26 and August 1 seeking preservation of records related to the US v. Epstein case. Weinberg requested Miller advise relevant parties, including US Attorneys in Georgia and CEOS, of the preservation request due on September 13. The expected response timeline was extended slightly due to a follow-up letter received on August 1, with an initial goal of a response by tomorrow (August 9th) or no later than Monday.

An email chain discusses ongoing investigations related to the case of *US v. Epstein*. A press release from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) was sent to Michael Miller, Marty, and Reid Weingarten, indicating investigations initiated by the Attorney General, including a potential FBI investigation into the cause of death. Further information regarding the apparent cause of death and Mr. Epstein’s observation status is pending.

Michael Miller inquired about confirmation of Jeffrey Epstein’s death via email to Martin G. Weinberg and Reid Weingarten on August 10, 2019. Weinberg responded on July 26, 2019, acknowledging receipt and sending a formal preservation/production request for materials related to the US v. Epstein case.

An email was sent forwarding correspondence regarding the US v. Epstein case. The email directs Michael Miller to copy Martin Weinberg and Reid Weingarten as legal counsel for notifications, providing their email addresses.

Michael Miller forwarded a press release regarding the US v. Epstein case, sourced from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP). The press release contains all available information from BOP. He confirms an FBI investigation into the death has been initiated and anticipates it will be rigorous.

Martin G. Weinberg contacted [REDACTED] regarding the US v. Epstein case, specifically concerning emails related to Mr. Epstein’s death and preservation/production requests from his family. Weinberg requested DNA collection from evidence at Mr. Epstein’s cell and a taint review of any email or residence seizure reviews. He inquired about the government’s intention to dismiss the indictment and requested the name of the assigned taint attorney.

An email exchange occurred on August 12, 2019, regarding the US v. Epstein case. The sender, Martin G. Weinberg, Esq., received an email requesting the forwarding of emails related to Ghislaine Maxwell Epstein (referred to as “Mr. E” and “Mr. E h”) and preservation/production requests on behalf of her family. The sender also requested DNA collection from Epstein’s cell and a taint review of emails from Teterboro and his NYC residence. Finally, the sender inquired about the government’s intention to dismiss the indictment.

Martin G. Weinberg emailed Marty, Michael Miller, Reid Weingarten, and Alex regarding a potential civil forfeiture discussion related to the US v. Epstein case. He offered availability at 9:30 AM the following morning and requested a dial-in be circulated.

Martin G. Weinberg, Esq., and Michael Reid Weingarten are authorized to discuss potential civil forfeiture issues related to the US v. Epstein case. Weinberg is offering to speak with the recipient at 9:30 AM the following day, August 15, 2019, to hear their perspective.
Emails between individuals regarding the upload of PDF files related to the US v. Epstein case to Relativity. The files were processed by a vendor and initially duplicated from Florida case files.

This document is a letter from U.S. District Judge Richard M. Berman to Professor Bruce A. Green regarding Green’s expert opinion and opinion piece concerning the U.S. v. Epstein case. Green was retained as an expert on legal ethics and provided an affidavit recommending the disqualification of David Boies from representing Ghislaine Maxwell. Judge Berman expresses surprise that this recommendation wasn't disclosed alongside Green’s opinion piece and questions Green’s interpretation of Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 57 and the Crime Victims' Rights Act, arguing the piece may have attempted to silence Maxwell and Boies. The letter is copied to Martin G. Weinberg, Reid Weingarten, and David Boies.

On October 17, 2019, at 7:30 PM GMT, Marc A. Weinstein attended a Skype meeting (Conference ID: 598 437 033) related to the US v. Epstein civil forfeiture matter. The event was classified as X-PERSONAL. The meeting was created on October 17, 2019, at 3:22 PM GMT and last modified at that time.

An email exchange discusses discrepancies in notification numbers related to a case ("US V. Epstein") and a file named "Bookl.xlsx". One party (USANYS) notes individuals appearing multiple times and questions the difference between a reported notification count of 39 and a count of 43 under "notify". The emails are sent between individuals affiliated with USANYS.
An email dated November 12, 2019, from "ll" to [REDACTED] with the subject "Read: US v. Epstein" and tracking number EFTA00020983, indicates a review of the US v. Jeffrey Epstein case.

On November 12, 2019, an individual ([REDACTED]) contacted another individual ([REDACTED]) regarding the completion of document unitization and coding from 56 DVD files related to the US v. Epstein case. The vendor had finished this work. The individual requested the return of the DVDs and offered to return them upon their return to the office. They also inquired about reviewing the vendor's work product before uploading it to Relativity and proposed a meeting early next week to discuss.
An email was sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] regarding a case titled “US v. Epstein.” The email subject was “Read: RE: US v. Epstein” and was dated November 12, 2019.

This email discusses a civil forfeiture matter, “US v. Epstein,” involving the EFTA00028831 document. It provides dial-in numbers and conference ID information for meetings, including options for one-touch dial-in from mobile phones and connecting via computer or network. It also offers troubleshooting advice for joining meetings via Skype for Business.

An automatic reply email was sent from [REDACTED] regarding the US v. Epstein case. The sender stated they would be out of the office until November 15th, with potential delays in responses, and directed urgent matters to other AUSA(s) on the case. The case file is EFTA00020905.

An email exchange discusses the return of DVDs containing data unitized and coded from 56 DVD files related to the case *US v. Epstein*. One party requests the DVDs be provided for case file storage and asks about reviewing the vendor’s work product before uploading it to Relativity. The other party indicates they will return the DVDs and offers to meet next week to discuss review.

This document refers to email correspondence related to case EFTA00016396, specifically the US v. Epstein case. The emails were saved on \\Usa.doj.gov\cloud\NYS\StAndrewAShared\USvEpstein-2018R0161Mitnesses & Cooperators and include an image named image001.png. The emails span from December 16, 2019.

An individual received a dataset from the FBI related to the US v. Epstein case. The dataset contained issues including a lack of functionality to link emails and attachments, a missing link between the load file and native files, and mismatched control numbers. The sender requested the FBI to resend the data with these corrections applied.

An email chain discusses issues with a dataset provided by the FBI related to the US v. Epstein case. The dataset lacks functionality to link emails and attachments, has a broken link to native files, and contains mismatched control numbers. The sender requests the FBI to correct these issues and resend the data.

An email was sent from [REDACTED] to an unknown recipient regarding the delivery of a hard drive related to the case "US v. Epstein." The sender stated they were prepared to send the hard drive to a vendor by the following day and requested instructions on whether to proceed with sending the data or to hold off.

On July 14, 2020, a contractor (USANYS) received new data related to the US v. Epstein case from IM. The processing and uploading cost was estimated at $8,000.00, and the data was intended to be sent to PAE, requesting approval from the recipient. EFTA00027569 is the case identifier.

An email exchange discusses discrepancies regarding provided data related to the US v. Epstein case. One party (identified as [REDACTED]) questions the provision of NYCO24392 and NYCO24328, noting the absence of those identifiers in attached spreadsheets and a list of devices. Folders containing data related to NYCO24363, NYCO24392, NYCO24328, NYCO24365, NYCO24366, NYCO24371, and NYCO24383 are being sent for upload to Relativity.

An email request was sent to create specific Relativity database tags for a review of documents related to the “US v. Epstein” case. The requested tags include: Reviewed, Witness Statement, Produce As Is, Produce With Redactions, Produce As Confidential, Produce As Highly Confidential, Work Product (Do Not Produce), Potential Brady, Hot Doc, For Further Review, and Tech Issue.

An individual requested the creation of specific tags within the “US v. Epstein” Relativity database: Reviewed, Witness Statement, Produce As Is, Produce With Redactions, Produce As Confidential, Produce As Highly Confidential, Work Product (Do Not Produce), Potential Brady, Hot Doc, For Further Review, and Tech Issue. The tags were subsequently created and made available for use.

On September 23, 2020, an individual ([REDACTED]) created tags in the Relativity database ("US v. Epstein") for EFTA00019847 and EFTA00019848. The tags included: Reviewed, Witness Statement, Produce As Is, Produce With Redactions, Produce As Confidential, Produce As Highly Confidential, Work Product (Do Not Produce), Potential Brady, Hot Doc, For Further Review, and Tech Issue. A discussion regarding reviewing batches to ensure consistency was proposed for 4:00 PM that day.

*   The files are initially copied to a drive and will be uploaded to the Relativity database under the folder “US v. Epstein 4 FBI Case File 4 Images Seized During Search.” *   Requests are made regarding the stamping process (Confidential stamp, Bates number, preferred production format - TIFF images, database load files, or PDF), and clarification is given that searching the files after they've been loaded to Relativity is not possible due to their format. *   There is discussion about the appropriate handling of privileged review (only warrant returns should be privileged) and the lack of a confidential stamp option for Excel files. *   A link to the Relativity database is provided for review.

The email chain concerns tagging and renaming files within the “US v. Epstein” Relativity database. Requests include: 1.  Removal of the “responsiveness review” field. 2.  Creation of the tag “3600”. 3.  Breaking the folder into review batches of 500 documents, assigning them to three recipients (including MI). 4.  Renaming the “Florida Investigation FOIA Files_2” folder to “FBI Files from Florida Office”. 5.  Implementing tags: “Reviewed”, “Witness Statement”, “Produce As Is”, “Produce With Redactions”, “Produce As Confidential”, “Produce As Highly Confidential”, “Work Product (Do Not Produce)”, “Potential Brady”, “Hot Doc”, “For Further Review”, and “Tech Issue”. 6.  Desire for all tags to be in one or multiple fields, and across both Epstein Relativity databases.

On October 30, 2020, multiple individuals (USANYS, [REDACTED]) discussed a delay in producing discovery related to the US v. Epstein case. The delay stemmed from significant processing time required for data received from FedEx, specifically 1.2 million records currently being imaged and processed. Hard drives containing productions (SDNYPROD008-014) were being sent to SDNY via FedEx, with the earliest images available on November 2nd.  A key concern was the unlikelihood of meeting the November 9th deadline, potentially requiring explanation to the Court and impacting the team’s workload under Judge Nathan.  The sender, Nick Koontz, indicated a possible timeline of Tuesday for a more concrete estimate.

Epstein. *   Production consists of 40,000 images, FBI Florida boxes, and FBI FOIA documents. *   Electronic devices are not being produced. *   FedEx is delivering data in batches, with a significant amount still being processed and imaged. *   Specific hard drives (SDNYPROD008-014) containing approximately 1.2 million records are being sent to SDNY. *   The initial target date for record availability is November 2, 2020, with production starting shortly after. *   The initial target date for completion was November 9, 2020, but this is now unlikely. A revised estimate will be provided early next week. *   PAE is providing the documents on a rolling basis.

On November 2, 2020, a request was made to produce documents from the “NYC024348”, “NYC024349”, and “NYC024350” folders within the “US v. Epstein (SW Returns)” database. Specifically, 347 documents were tagged as “Identified Responsive” in one folder, 39 in another, and 4,897 in the third. A vendor inquired about the scope of the search, and confirmations were received regarding the planned production. On October 28, 2020, a new request was submitted for searches on the same folders, using specific search terms and email addresses, all tagged as “Potentially Responsive.” The goal was to identify potentially responsive documents for review and subsequent production.

An email was sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] regarding the case “US v. Epstein” accessed through the SW database. The email, dated November 13, 2020, was attached and included the message ID <BN3P110MB026018BCA88B68BCC7A8C34CE3E60®.BN3P110MB0260.NAMP110.PROD.OUTLOOK.COM>.  The email subject was “RE: US v. Epstein (SW database)”.

The following exchanges concern a review of searches conducted for the “US v. Epstein” case. *   An individual requests exclusion of “Junk Search Terms (From)” hits from a responsiveness search and wants the search results saved. *   A subsequent request asks for the removal of the “Junk Search Terms (Keywords)” search, focusing solely on the “Epstein — Junk Search Terms (From)” search and running a responsiveness search on the remaining documents. *   A reviewer examines the searches and identifies the “Junk Search Terms (Keywords)” search as incorrectly identifying responsive documents. They request the search be run only on email files. *   Confirmation is received that the searches in the US v. Epstein database are complete and ready for review. *   Specific search queries for the US v. Epstein case are listed: “Epstein - Junk Search Terms (From)” and “Epstein - Junk Search Terms (Keywords)”.

An email was sent from a USANYSCorner contractor to MINIIIr regarding a review of searches conducted within the US v. Epstein database. The searches included variations of “Epstein” and “Junk Search Terms,” with varying levels of confidentiality requested. The email requested confirmation of questions or issues.

This document is an email chain related to the US v. Jeffrey Epstein case. The email was sent from a USANYS contractor to multiple recipients, including [REDACTED] and [REDACTED], and contains attachments related to the case. The email subject line is “US v. Epstein.”

The email chain discusses a significant delay in the processing of data for the US v. Epstein case. Approximately 1.2 million records are being imaged and processed by PAE, with FedEx involvement. The initial deadline of November 9th is now considered unachievable. The team is concerned about the impact on discovery timelines and potential issues with Judge Nathan. Hard drives containing productions (SDNYPROD008-013) are being sent to Sony via FedEx. An update is expected early next week, potentially requiring a broader explanation to the court.

Epstein case. *   The team is experiencing significant delays (1-2 months) in receiving processed data from Relativity. *   Approximately 1.2 million records are being imaged and will be available for production starting Monday, November 2nd. *   Hard drives containing productions SDNYPROD008 through SDNYPROD014 are being sent to SDNY via FedEx. *   A key concern is the potential impact on deadlines, particularly the November 9th deadline, and the possibility of requiring a court explanation. *   The sender anticipates a more concrete update early next week.
An email chain discusses the hard drive password EFTA00024795 related to the US v. Epstein case. The password was provided by a contractor (USANYS) and sent to another redacted contractor.
The email discusses the hard drive password EFTA00024794 related to the case of US v. Epstein, sent by a USANYS contractor.

A request was made to redact access to specific documents within the “US v. Epstein (SW Returns)” database. Specifically, 397,365 documents not tagged “Identified Responsive” were to be locked off, leaving 1,218,719 tagged documents accessible. The contractor, USANYS, was tasked with executing this redaction and placing the non-responsive documents in designated subfolders within the FBI’s Di Search Warrant Returns and New_Search Warrant Returns folders.

A vendor is producing seven parts of a redacted document related to the US v. Epstein case (SW database) for the recipient. Parts 1-3 have been completed and exported, with Part 4 preparation underway. The vendor is using searches Q SDNY_PROD015 - PART 01, Q SDNY_PROD015 - PART 02, and Q SDNY_PROD015 - PART 03 to manage the production.

On December 8, 2020, a contractor (USANYS) requested confirmation that a search within the “US v. Epstein (SW Returns)” database should be marked as Non-Responsive and locked off. The contractor proposed placing the Non-Responsive documents in subfolders within the “al Search Warrant Returns” and “USvE_20200728” parent folders. On December 4, 2020, a request was made to lock off access to 397,365 documents not tagged “Identified Responsive,” leaving 1,218,719 tagged documents accessible.

A search terms report related to the US v. Epstein case was generated on December 8, 2020. The report details the searchable set “STR - Search Terms - OPR,” containing 300,123 documents.  A total of 5,462 documents had hits, including 11,692 hits with family terms.  The report then provides a term summary listing numerous search terms and the number of documents associated with each term, with corresponding hits and hits including family terms. The total number of documents without hits is 288,431.

Two contractors ([REDACTED] and [REDACTED]) are handling the production of materials related to the US v. Epstein case. Two hard drives containing copies of productions 15 & 16 were received from PAE. The vendor is stamping and exporting portions of the production data (parts 1-6) from Relativity. Part 4 is partially stamped, and the vendor is requesting a potential extension from Judge Nathan. The contractor is monitoring the progress and coordinating with other parties regarding the delivery of the hard drives.

Two emails were exchanged regarding the review of documents related to the US v. Maxwell and US v. Epstein cases. Chris ([REDACTED]) was requested by [REDACTED] to create batches of approximately 500 documents from the "USAO-SDFL Files" folder within the "US v Epstein" database, tagging them with "Relevant to NPA." The batches were subsequently created and tagged in the database.

A request was sent from the Maxwell team to [REDACTED] to review documents related to “US v. Maxwell” and “US v. Epstein” using Relativity. The request involved creating batches of approximately 500 documents from the “USAO-SDFL Files” folder within the “US v Epstein” database and applying the “Relevant to NPA” Issue Designation tag to existing tags.

On January 7, 2021, a vendor was tasked with uploading data related to “portal access (v2)/US v. Epstein” to Relativity. The vendor initially removed old data and then received a new dataset from a source.  Multiple individuals confirmed the data transfer and requested its review. A ShareFile link was provided for access to the uploaded data.  The data included Florida scanned data which was intended to be removed and replaced by the new vendor data. There was an issue with the initial link, resulting in duplicate emails.

The document is a series of email exchanges concerning the upload of data related to a case ("US v. Epstein") to a portal.  A vendor was tasked with removing old data from Relativity and replacing it with a new dataset.  There were multiple requests for updates on the upload status, and the vendor confirmed the data was being processed and eventually uploaded.  A link to ShareFile was repeatedly sent to facilitate access to the data, alongside assurances of support in case of access issues.  The email also includes a standard confidentiality notice.

On February 17, 2021, a contractor (USANYS) informed a user that a “filepath” field has been added to the "Epstein Relativity Database" to display the NYC serial number of documents. This follows a previous request from the user to add a column to the database showing the NYC serial number for documents related to “US v. Epstein (SW Returns).” The contractor provided a screenshot illustrating the use of the “filepath” field. The Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York is listed as EFTA00028202.

A request was made by an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York to Chris (USANYS Contractor) regarding adding a column to the "US v. Epstein (SW Returns)" Relativity database to display the NYC serial number for each document. The request stemmed from a previous assistance Chris provided in adding this column. The email chain details the specific query and the desired action.

A search terms report related to the US v. Epstein case was generated on March 15, 2021. The report utilized a searchable set named “STR - Search Terms - OPR.” It details the number of documents containing specific search terms, broken down into hits and hits including “Family” hits. Key terms and their associated hit counts include "Ghislaine Maxwell," “gmax,” and “Maxwell,” along with numerous other terms. The report lists totals for documents with hits, documents with hits including family hits, and unique hits for each term. There were 32,986 documents with hits and 267,137 documents without hits.

On March 25, 2021, communications occurred regarding a discussion about the US v. Epstein case. Multiple individuals, including contractors associated with "USANYS" and PAE, requested a call at 4:30 PM to discuss loading scanning data onto Relativity. There were multiple confirmations and adjustments to the proposed time.

This document is a redaction analysis related to a case, "US v. Epstein," originating from an email between "n a" and [REDACTED] (USANYS) contractor. The email subject is "Read: US v. Epstein" and was sent on March 25, 2021.
This email, dated March 25, 2021, pertains to the case “US v. Epstein” and was sent from “na” to [REDACTED] (USANYS) as a contractor.

A communication titled "Read: US v. Epstein" was sent on April 1, 2021, from an unknown sender (identified as '1') to a redacted recipient. The subject was the US v. Epstein case, and it was designated as EFTA00027866.

PAE’s technical team determined that a saved search containing 109,853 EMLX files is comprised of empty attachments with image placeholders indicating export failure. The majority of the parent documents have “partial” in their filenames. These records likely represent missing attachments not captured by the data custodian. The document references a Relativity jgo link for the US v. Epstein (SW Returns) case.
An email was sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] regarding the case “US v. Epstein.” The email is labeled EFTA00025140.

An email chain discusses scheduling a call regarding “US v. Epstein.” The call was proposed for Wednesday at 12:30 PM between [REDACTED], [REDACTED], and a vendor. Attachments include a spreadsheet (Copy_of USVP00300765_-_Possible_PROD_BEG_BATES.xlsx) and references to previous conversations with EFTA00028703 and EFTA00028704.

This document is a Relativity review regarding the US v. Epstein case, specifically concerning SW returns (USGME01782221). It originated from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] and was sent on August 18, 2021, with a link to the Relativity platform (https://dIpe.nss.pae.com/Relativity/go?id=2370462-2823018).

The FBI has limited its review of materials related to Jeffrey Epstein’s devices to documents tagged "Responsive" in Relativity, images and videos identified as responsive, and specific iPad/iPhone portions flagged responsive by SDNY. Moving forward, the sender requests confirmation if any non-responsive material is encountered and proposes action to lock it off. A request is made to lock off 397,365 non-responsive documents from the “US v. Epstein (SW Returns)” database, leaving 1,218,719 responsive documents accessible.
